Still harping upon that ungrateful String!—but prithee don't ſet me a laughing again. — Offence! — nothing gives me Offence, Child:—You know I am very fond.— (yawns and walks)—I like you of all Things, and think you a moſt admirable Wife;— prudent, managing, — careleſs of your own Perſon, and very attentive to mine;— not much addicted to Pleaſure,—grave,—retir'd,— and domeſtic; — govern your Houſe,— pay the Tradeſmens Bills, (yawns) ſcold the Servants, and love your Huſband: — Upon my Soul, a very good Wife!—As good a Sort
of a Wife (yawns) as a body might wiſh to have.—Where's William?— I muſt go to Bed.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: To Bed ſo early! — Had not you better join the Company?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I ſhan't go out to Night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: But I mean the Company in the Dining-Room.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What Company? (ſtares at her.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: That I invited to a Rout.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: A Rout in my Houſe!— and you dreſſed out too!—What is all this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: You have no Objection, I hope—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Objection!—no,—I like Company, you know, of all Things;—I'll go and join them:—Who are they all?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love,
sp.p: You know 'em all;— and there's your Friend Sir Brilliant there,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Is he there?—I'm glad of it.—But pray now, how comes this about?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: I intend to do it often,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Do ye?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Ay, and not look tamely on, while you revel luxuriouſly in a Courſe of Pleaſure; I ſhall purſue my own Plan of Diverſion.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Do ſo, do ſo, Ma'am, the Change in your Temper will be very pleaſing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: I ſhall indeed, Sir, —I'm in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: By all means follow your own Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: And ſo I ſhall Sir, I aſſure ye (sings.)

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What the Devil is come over her? and what in the Name of Wonder, does all this mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Mean Sir! — it means — it means—it means—how can you aſk me what it means?—Well to be ſure, the Sobriety of that Queſtion! — Do you think a Woman of Spirit can have Leiſure to tell her Meaning, when ſhe is all Air, Alertneſs, Plcaſure, and Enjoyment?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: She's mad!—Stark mad!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p:
You're miſtaken, Sir,— not mad, but in Spirits, that's all;—no Offence I hope.—Am I too flighty for you?—perhaps I am, — you are of a ſaturnine Diſpoſition, inclin'd to think a little, or ſo.—Well don't let me interrupt you; don't let me be of any Inconvenience.—that would be the impoliteſt thing— for a married Couple to interfere and encroach on each other's Pleaſures, — Oh hideous!
it would be gothic to the laſt Degree Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: (forcing a Laugh,) Ha! ha! — Ma'am,—you, Ha! ha! you are perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Nay but I don't like that Laugh now,—I poſitively don't like it; —can't you laugh out as you were us'd to do? for my part, I'm determined to do nothing elſe all the reſt of my Life.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: This is the moſt aſtoniſhing thing! Ma'am, I don't rightly comprehend—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Oh Lud! Oh Lud! — with that important Face.—Well but come now, what don't you comprehend?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: There is ſomething in this Treatment that I don't ſo well —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Oh! are you there. Sir? — How quickly they, who have no Senſibility for the Peace and Happineſs of others, can feel for themſelves Mr. Lovemore! — But that's a grave Reflection, and I hate Reflection.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What has ſhe got into her Head?— This ſudden Change, Mrs. Lovemore, let me tell you, is a little alarming, and —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p:
Nay, don't be frighten'd, — there is no harm in innocent Mirth, I hope; —never look ſo grave upon it. — I aſſure ye, Sir, that tho' on your Part, you ſeem determined to offer conſtant Indignities to your Wife, — and tho' the Laws of Retaliation
wou'd in ſome ſort exculpate her, if, when provok'd to the utmoſt,—exaſperated beyond all enduring, ſhe ſhould in her Turn, make him know what it is to receive an Injury in the tendereſt Point—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam! (angrily.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Well, well, don't be frighten'd I ſay, I ſhan't retaliate: — my own Honour will ſecure you there; — you may depend upon it.—You won't come and play a Game at Cards?—Well, do as you like;—well,—you won't come? No, no, I ſee you won't.—What ſay you to a Bit of Supper with us? —Nor that neither?—Follow your Inclinations, it is not meterial where a body eats.—The Company expects me; your Servant Mr. Lovemore, yours, yours. (Exit, ſinging.)

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: alone. This is a Frolic I never ſaw her in before!—Laugh all the reſt of my Life!—Laws of Retaliation! — an Injury in the tendereſt Point! — the Company expects me,—your Servant my Dear, yours, yours!— (mimicking her) What the Devil is all this?— Some of her Female Friends have been tampering with her. —Zouns! — I muſt begin to look a little ſharp after Madam. — I'll go this Moment into the Card-Room, and watch whom ſhe whiſpers with, whom ſhe ogles with, and every Circumſtance that can lead to— (going)

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, — here's your Letter,—I wou'd not for all the World that my Maſter —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What, is ſhe mad too? What's the matter, Woman?

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir,—nothing,—I wanted a word with my Lady,—that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You wou'd not for the World that your Maſter,—What was you going'to ſay? —What Paper's that?

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: Paper, Sir!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let me ſee it.

sp.speaker: Muſtin.
sp.p: Lard, Sir!—how can you aſk a Body for ſuch a thing. It's a Letter to me, Sir, — a Letter from the Country, — a Letter from my Siſter, Sir.—ſhe bids me buy her a Shiver de Fize Cap, and a Sixteenth in the Lottery; and tells me of a Number ſhe dreamt of, that's all, Sir,—I'll put it up.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let me look at it,—give it me this Moment? (reads.) To Mrs. Lovemore! — Brilliant Faſhion. This is a Letter from the Country, is it?

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: That, Sir,—that is—no, Sir,—no, —that's not Siſter's Letter.—If you'll give me that back, Sir, I'll ſhew you the right one.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Where did you get this?

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Where did you get it? — Tell me Truth.

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: Dear heart, you fright a Body ſo —in the Parlour, Sir,—I found it there.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Very well!—Leave the Room.

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: The Devil fetch it, I was never ſo out in my Politicks, in all my Days. Exit.

sp.speaker: Love. alone.
sp.p: A pretty Epiſtle truly this ſeems to be,—let me read it.

div.p: "Permit me, dear Madam, to throw myſelf on my Knees, (for on my Knees I muſt addreſs you) and in that humble Poſture, to implore your Compaſſion."—Compaſſion with a Vengeance on him— (walks about) "Think you ſee me now with tender, melting, ſupplicating Eyes, languiſhing at your Feet:" — Very well, Sir, —"Can you find it in your Heart to perſiſt in Cruelty?—Grant me but Acceſs to you once more, and in addition to what I already ſaid this Morning, I will urge ſuch Motives"—urge Motives, will ye—"as will ſuggeſt to you, that you ſhou'd no longer heſitate in Gratitude, to reward him, who ſtill on his Knees, here makes a Vow to you of eternal Conſtancy and Love. Brilliant Faſhion."

So; ſo! ſo!—your very humble Servant, Sir Brilliant Faſhion!—This is your Friendſhip for me, is it?—you're mighty kind indeed, Sir,—but I thank you as much as if you had really done me the favour,— and, Mrs Lovemore, I'm your humble Servant too.—
She intends to laugh all the the reſt of her Life! This Letter will change her Note.— Odſo, yonder ſhe comes along the Gallery, and Sir Brilliant in full Chaſe of her.— They come this way, — cou'd I but detect them both now! — I'll ſtep aſide, and who knows but the Devil may tempt 'em to their undoing, — at leaſt I'll try, — a polite Huſband I am—There's the Coaſt clear for you, Madam. Exit.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Lovemore, Sir Brilliant after her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir Brilliant, your Civility is odious, — your Compliments fulſome, — and your Solicitations impertinent, Sir.—I muſt make uſe of harſh Language, Sir, — you provoke me to it and I can't refrain.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: By all my Hopes we are now conveniently alone, (aſide.) Not retiring to Solitude and Diſcontent again, I hope, Madam! —Have a Care, my dear Mrs. Lovemore of a Relapſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: No Danger of that, Sir, don't be ſolicitous about me. — Why wou'd you leave the Company? let me entreat you to return, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p:
By Heaven, there is more Rapture in being one Moment vis-a-vis with you, than in the Company of a whole Drawing-Room of Beauties.—Round you are melting
Pleaſures, tender Tranſports, youthful Loves, and blooming Graces, all unfelt, neglected, and deſpis'd, by a taſteleſs, cold, languid, unimpaſſion'd Huſband, while they might be all ſo much better employ'd to the Purpoſes of Extacy and Bliſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: I am amaz'd, Sir, at this Liberty,—what Action of my Life has authoriz'd ſuch barefac'd Aſſurance? — and for what Reaſon do you think ſo meanly of me, as to imagine that I have not a greater Regard for my Reputation, and for what the World may ſay, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: The World, Ma'am,—the World will juſtify you—ſhe ſerv'd him right —they will all agree in it,—there will be but one Opinion about it, — that is, Ma'am, if the World ſhould know it;—but our Loves may be as concealed, as Secrets undiſcover'd yet by mortal Eye. — By all that's ſoft, it goes down with her like a Diſh of Tea. (aſide.) And ſo, Madam, ſince I have convinc'd you, —and ſince the Time, the Place, and mutual Ardor all concur —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Sir, I am not to be treated in this Manner,— and, I aſſure you, Sir, that were I not afraid of the evil Conſequences that might follow, I ſhould not heſitate a Moment to acquaint Mr. Lovemore with your whole Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p:
She won't tell her Huſband then, —charming Creature, and Bleſſings on her
for ſo convenient a Hint,—ſhe yields, by all that's wicked!—What ſhall I ſay to overwhelm her Senſes in a Flood of Nonſenſe? aſide.

div.l: Go my Heart's Envoys, tender Sighs make haſte,—
Still drink delicious Poiſon from thy Eye, —
Pant on thy Lip, and to thy Heart be preſs'd.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Zoons, this is too much.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: What the Devil's the Matter now? (Kneels down to buckle his Shoe.) This confounded Buckle is always plaguing me.—My dear Boy, Lovemore,—I rejoice to ſee thee, They ſtand looking at each other.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And have you the Confidence to look me in the Face?

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: I was telling your Lady here, of the moſt whimſical Adventure —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Don't add the Meanneſs of Falſhood, to the black Attempt of invading your Friend's Happineſs. — I did imagine, Sir, from the long Intercourſe that has ſubſiſted between us, that you might have had Delicacy enough, Feeling enough, Honour enough, Sir,—not to meditate an Injury like this.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: Ay, ay, it's all over, I'm detected. (aſide.) Mr. Lovemore, if begging your Pardon for this Raſhneſs will any ways atone—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No, Sir, nothing can atone. The Provocation you have given me, wou'd juſtify my drawing upon you this Inſtant, did not that Lady and this Roof protect you.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: But Mr.Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But, Sir —

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: I only beg—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, — Sir, I inſiſt—I won't hear a word.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: I declare, upon my Honour —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Honour! for Shame, Sir Brilliant, don't uſe the Word.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: If begging Pardon of that Lady —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That Lady!—I deſire you will never ſpeak to that Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: Nay, but prithee, Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No, Sir, no,—I have done with you for the preſent.—As for you, Madam, I am ſatisfy'd with your Conduct.—I was indeed, a little alarm'd, but I was a Witneſs of your Behaviour, and I'm above harbouring low Suſpicions.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: Allow me but a Word —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No more, Sir, I have done —

sp.speaker: Sir. Brill.
sp.p: Let me but explain—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Zoons!—I'll go into another Room to avoid you. (Going,.ſees Mrs. Bellmour.) Hell and Deſtruction, what Fiend is conjur'd up here?—Zounds, let me make my Eſcape out of the Houſe. (Runs to the other Door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: I'll ſecure this Door, — you muſt not go, my Dear. Stops him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: S'death, Madam, let me paſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Nay, you ſhall ſtay, I want to introduce an Acquaintance of mine to you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I deſire, Madam —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord Etheridge; I am heartily glad to ſee your Lordſhip. (taking hold of him.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Do my Dear, let me introduce this Lady to you. (turning, him to her.)

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Here's the Devil and all to do! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: My Lord, this is the moſt fortunate Encounter —

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I wiſh I was Fifty Miles off. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Mrs. Bellmour, give me Leave to introduce Mr. Lovemore to you. (turning him to her.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: No, my dear Ma'am, let me introduce Lord Etheridge to you. (pulling him) My Lord —

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: In the Name of Wonder, what is all this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: My dear Ma'am, you're miſtaken; this is my Huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Pardon me, Ma'am, 'tis my Lord Etheridge.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: My Dear, how can you be ſo ill-bred in your own Houſe?—Mrs. Bellmour, —this is Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Are you going to toſs me in a Blanket, Madam?—call up the reſt of your People, if you are.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Pſhaw!—Prithee now, my Lord, leave off your Humours;—Mrs. Lovemore, this is my Lord Etheridge, a Lover of mine, who has made Propoſals of Marriage to me,

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Confuſion! let me get rid of theſe two Furies. (breaks away from them.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: (follows him,)—My Lord I ſay! my Lord Etheridge! — won't your Lordſhip know me?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: This is the moſt damnable Accident! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: I hope your Lordſhip has not forgot your Appointment at my Houſe this Evening.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ay now my Turn is come, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Prithee, my Lord, what have I done, that you treat me with this Coldneſs? Come, come, you ſhall have a Wife, I will take Compaſſion on you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Damnation! I can't ſtand this, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p:
Come, cheer up, my Lord;— What the duce, your Dreſs is alter'd!—What's become of the Star and the Ribband?—And ſo the gay, the florid, the magniſique Lord Etheridge, dwindles down into plain Mr. Lovemore, the Married Man! Mr. Lovemore,
your moſt obedient, very humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I can't bear to feel my myſelf in ſo ridiculous a Circumſtance. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: I beg my Compliments to your Friend Mrs. Leveit; and I am much oblig'd to you both for your very honourable Deſigs.— (curtſeying to him.)

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I never was ſo aſham'd in all my Life! —

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo, all his Pains were to hide the Star from me.—The Diſcovery is a perfect Cordial to my dejected Spirits.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Mrs. Lovemore, I cannot ſufficiently acknowledge the Providence, that directed you to pay me a Viſit, tho' I was wholly unknown to you; and I ſhall henceforth conſider you as my Deliverer.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Zoons! It was ſhe that fainted away in the Cloſet, and be damn'd to her Jealouſy, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: By all that's whimſical, an odd ſort of an Adventure this — my Lord, (advances to him.) My Lord, — my Lord Etheriage, as the Man ſays in the Play, "Your Lordſhip's right welcome back to Denmark."

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now he comes upon me.—Oh! I'm in a fine Situation, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: My Lord, I hope that ugly Pain in your Lordſhip's Side, is abated.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Abſurd, and ridiculous, (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: There is nothing forming there I hope, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: (apart with Mrs. Bellmour,) I begin now to feel for him, and to pity his Uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, don't you think it a baſe Thing to invade the Happineſs of a Friend? Or to do him a clandeſtine Wrong? or to injure him with the Woman he loves?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: To cut the Matter ſhort with you, Sir, we are both Raſcals.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ay both! We are two very pretty Fellows indeed!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: I am glad to find that you are at length awaken'd into a Senſe of your Error. (to Lovemore.)

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I am, Madam, and I am frank enough to own it. — I am above attempting to diſguiſe my Feelings, when I am conſcious they are on the Side of Truth and Honour;— and Madam, with a true Remorſe, — I aſk your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Upon certain Terms, I don't know but I may ſign and ſeal your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Terms! What Terms?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: That you make due Expiation of your Guilt to that Lady.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That Lady, Ma'am! — That Lady has no Reaſon to complain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: No Reaſon to complain, Mr. Lovemore!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No Madam, — none! for whatever may have been my Imprudences, they have had their Source in your Conduct.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: In my Conduct, Sir!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: In your Conduct!—I here declare before this Company, —and I am above palliating the Matter, I here declare, that no Man in England cou'd be better inclin'd to domeſtic Happineſs, if you, Madam, on your Part, had been willing to make Home agreeable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: There I confeſs he touches me. (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You cou'd take Pains enough before Marriage, — you would put forth all your Charms,—practice all your Arts,—and make your Features pleaſe by Rule;—for ever changing, — running an eternal Round of Variety: —And all this to win my Affections: — But when you had won them, you did not think them worth your keeping.— Never dreſs'd, — penſive, — ſilent, —melancholy;—and the only Entertainment in my Houſe, was the dear Pleaſure of a dull conjugal Tete-a-Tete; and all this Inſipidity, becauſe you think the ſole Merit of a Wife conſiſts in her Virtue:—A fine Way of amuſing a Huſband truly!

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: Upon my Soul, and ſo it is.— (laughing)

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: O Gemini! Gemini! here's ſuch a Piece of work,—what ſhall I do?— my poor dear Lady! (Crying bitterly.)

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Is the Woman crazy?

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, — forgive me, my dear Madam,—I did not do it on purpoſe,— as I hope for Mercy, I did not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: What did not you do?

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p:
I did not intend to give it him, I would have ſeen him gibbetted firſt. — I found the Letter in the Parlour, Madam, —I knew it was the ſame Letter I had deliver'd to you, and my Curioſity did make me peep into it. — Says my Curioſity, — "Now, Muſlin, you may gratify yourſelf by finding out the Contents of that Letter, which you have ſuch a violent Itching for." — My Curioſity ſaid ſo, Ma'am, and then, I own, Ma'am, my Reſpect for you did ſay to me, "Huſſey, how dare you meddle with what does not belong to you?— keep your Diſtance, and let your Miſtreſs's Secrets alone."—But then upon that, in comes my Curioſity again, and ſays my Curioſity, "Read it, I tell you, Muſlin, a Woman of Spirit ſhou'd know every thing."—"Let it alone, you Jade," ſays my Reſpect.—"It's as much as your Place is worth."—"There's more Places than one," ſays my Curioſity, "and ſo read it, I tell you, Muſlin,"—I did read it,
— what could I do? Heaven help me, —I did read it,—I don't go to deny it,—I don't, I don't. (Crying.)

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Don't keep ſuch an Uproar, Woman.

sp.speaker: Muſlin.
sp.p: And then, after I read it, thinks me, I, I'll give this to my Miſtreſs directly, and that perſidious thing her Huſband ſhall not ſee it; — and ſo as my ill Stars would wou'd have it, as I was looking for you, I run my hand full in the Lion's mouth. Crying.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: What an unlucky Jade it has been! (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Well have done, Muſlin; this is too much.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Upon my word but ſhe gives him his own.—I ſuppoſe you own the Truth of what ſhe ſays, Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, does that Lady own the Truth of what I have ſaid?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Sir, I am ſenſible there is too much Truth in what you ſay; this Lady has open'd my Eyes, and convinc'd me that there was a Miſtake in my former Conduct.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come, come, you need not ſay any more—I forgive you,—I forgive you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Forgive me! I like that Air of Confidence, when you know, that on my Side, it is at worſt, an Error in Judgment, whereas on yours —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Come, come, you know each other's Faults and Virtues, and ſo you have nothing to do but to mend the former, and enjoy the latter.—There, — there, kiſs and Friends.—There, Mrs. Lovemore, take your reclaim'd Libertine to your Arms.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It is in your Power, Madam, to make a reclaim'd Libertine of me indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: From this Moment it ſhall be our mutual Study to pleaſe each other. They embrace.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill. Lovemore,
sp.p: may I preſume to hope for Pardon at that Lady's Hands?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: My dear Confederate in Vice, your Pardon is granted.—Two ſad Dogs we have been,—but come, give us your Hand,—we have us'd each other damnably—for the future we will endeavour to make each other amends.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: And ſo we will.—Ma'am, ſince my Lord decamps from before the Town, may I preſume to hope—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: I poſitively forbid you the leaſt Grain of Hope; whenever I take to myſelf a Huſband, I muſt be convinc'd firſt that he will anſwer the Trouble of keeping him.

sp.speaker: Sir Brill.
sp.p: My dear Ma'am, by all that's—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: No Swearing—I poſitively will have my own way; you ſhall perform Quarantine before I ſpeak to you again.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: She's your's Man, ſhe's your's, — ſhe'll throw herſelf into your Arms in a Day or two.— And now I heartily congratulate the whole Company, that this Buſineſs has had ſo happy a Tendency to convince each of us of our Folly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, don't draw me into Share of your Folly.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come, come, my dear Ma'am, you are not without your Share of it. This will teach you for the future, to be content with one Lover at a time, without liſtening to a Fellow you know nothing of, — becauſe he aſſumes a Title, and reports well of himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bell.
sp.p: The Reproof is juſt, I grant it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come, let us join the Company chearfully, keep our own Secrets, and not make ourſelves a Town-Talk;— though, I don't know but if this Tranſaction were ſent abroad into the World, it might prove a very uſeful Leſſon. The Men wou'd ſee how their Paffions may carry them into the Danger of wounding the Boſom of a Friend,— the Ladies wou'd learn, that after the Marriage Rites, they ſhou'd not ſuffer their Powers of pleaſing to languish away, but ſhou'd ſtill remember to ſacrifice to the Graces.
sp.l: To win a Man, when all your Pains ſucceed.
The Way to Keep Him, is a Taſk indeed.
